hero.title: Cultivating Connections, Harvesting Prosperity
hero.subtitle: We're on a mission to digitize and connect the global agricultural supply chain, empowering every stakeholder from soil to shelf.

vision.title: Our Vision for a Connected Future
vision.p1: DamDoh was born from a simple yet powerful idea: that technology can bridge the gaps in the agricultural world. We envision a world where smallholder farmers have direct access to global markets, where buyers can source produce with verifiable confidence, and where knowledge flows freely to create a more sustainable and equitable food system.
vision.p2: We are more than a platform; we are a community dedicated to solving real-world challenges with innovative, user-centric solutions.

challenge.title: The Fragmented Landscape of Agriculture
challenge.description: The agricultural supply chain is a complex and often disconnected ecosystem, presenting numerous challenges for everyone involved.
details: Smallholder farmers struggle to connect with larger, more profitable markets.
Poor coordination leads to high costs and significant post-harvest losses.
Lack of formal records bars access to credit, loans, and insurance.
Farmers lack access to modern techniques and real-time market data.
Buyers face uncertainty about the quality, origin, and farming practices of produce.
Increasing unpredictability requires more resilient farming systems.
A significant portion of food is lost between the farm and the consumer.
Siloed information prevents a holistic view of the supply chain.

solution.title: The DamDoh Solution: An Integrated Ecosystem
solution.description: We address these challenges by providing a single, unified platform with tools for everyone.

p2p.title: Peer-to-Peer
p2p.content: Farmers connecting with other farmers to share knowledge and form cooperatives.

p2b.title: Producer-to-Business
p2b.content: Direct links between farmers and buyers, processors, and exporters, cutting out unnecessary middlemen.

p2e.title: Producer-to-Expert
p2e.content: Access to agronomists, financial advisors, and logistics providers to improve operations.

p2w.title: Producer-to-World
p2w.content: Enabling smallholder farmers to participate in the global marketplace with confidence and transparency.

commitment.title: Join Our Growing Ecosystem
commitment.p1: Our commitment is to the people who feed the world. We believe that by providing the digital tools they need, we can foster a more resilient, profitable, and sustainable agricultural sector for generations to come.
commitment.p2: Whether you're planting a seed, buying in bulk, or financing a farm, you have a place in the DamDoh community.

careers.title: Careers at DamDoh
careers.subtitle: Join our team and help build the future of agriculture.

whyWorkWithUs.title: Why Work With Us?
whyWorkWithUs.intro: At DamDoh, you'll be part of a passionate, mission-driven team dedicated to making a real-world impact. We offer:
whyWorkWithUs.point1: A collaborative and innovative work environment.
whyWorkWithUs.point2: The opportunity to solve complex challenges in a global industry.
whyWorkWithUs.point5: A culture of continuous learning and professional growth.

job1.title: Senior Frontend Engineer (Next.js)
job1.description: We're looking for an experienced Next.js developer to lead the development of our user-facing applications. You'll work with modern technologies to build a fast, scalable, and intuitive platform.

job2.title: AI/ML Engineer - Genkit Specialist
job2.description: Join our AI team to build and deploy intelligent features using Genkit and Google's AI stack. You will work on projects like crop diagnosis, market prediction, and intelligent matching.

job3.title: Head of Partnerships - AgriBusiness
job3.description: Lead our efforts to build strategic partnerships with key players in the agricultural ecosystem, including financial institutions, NGOs, and government agencies.

noOpenings.title: No Openings Right Now
noOpenings.content1: We're always looking for talented individuals passionate about our mission. If you don't see a role that fits, feel free to send your resume and a cover letter to

communityGuidelines.title: Community Guidelines
communityGuidelines.subtitle: Fostering a professional, respectful, and collaborative environment.
communityGuidelines.intro: Welcome to the DamDoh community! Our mission is to connect the global agricultural supply chain. To ensure a positive and productive experience for everyone, we ask all members to adhere to the following guidelines.

respectful.title: Be Respectful and Professional
respectful.description: Treat all members with respect, even when you disagree. Harassment, hate speech, and personal attacks will not be tolerated. Maintain a professional tone suitable for a global business network.

authentic.title: Be Authentic and Honest
authentic.description: Represent yourself and your business accurately. Do not misrepresent your products, services, or certifications. Authenticity is the foundation of trust on our platform.

relevant.title: Stay On-Topic and Constructive
relevant.description: Keep your posts and comments relevant to the forum or discussion topic. Share knowledge, ask thoughtful questions, and provide constructive feedback. Spam, self-promotion outside of designated areas, and irrelevant content may be removed.

fairTrade.title: Promote Fair Trade Practices
fairTrade.description: Engage in fair and ethical business practices. Negotiate in good faith, fulfill your commitments, and communicate clearly and honestly in all transactions and interactions.

sustainable.title: Encourage Sustainability
sustainable.description: We are a platform dedicated to improving the agricultural ecosystem. We encourage discussions and practices that promote environmental sustainability, soil health, and long-term ecological balance.

reporting.title: Reporting Violations
reporting.content: If you see content or behavior that violates these guidelines, please report it to our team at {emailLink}. We are committed to maintaining a safe and professional community.

communityGuidelines.conclusion: Thank you for being a part of the DamDoh community and helping us build a better future for agriculture.

industryNewsPage.description: Stay informed with the latest trends, research, and policy updates in global agriculture.

news1.title: Global Grain Prices Surge Amidst Weather Concerns in Key Exporting Regions
news1.excerpt: Wheat and corn futures have seen a significant increase this week as drought conditions in North America and excessive rain in South America raise concerns about future supply.

news2.title: EU Implements Stricter Regulations on Sustainable Packaging for Food Imports
news2.excerpt: A new set of regulations effective January 1st will require all food products imported into the European Union to meet stringent new standards for recyclable and compostable packaging.

news3.title: Study Shows Regenerative Agriculture Practices Can Boost Farm Profitability by 20%
news3.excerpt: A five-year study published in 'Nature Food' demonstrates that farms adopting regenerative practices like no-till and cover cropping saw increased profitability and soil health.

privacyPolicy.title: Privacy Policy
privacyPolicy.introduction: This privacy notice for DamDoh ('we', 'us', or 'our'), describes how and why we might collect, store, use, and/or share ('process') your information when you use our services ('Services').

whatInfoWeCollect.heading: 1. WHAT INFORMATION DO WE COLLECT?
whatInfoWeCollect.content: We collect personal information that you voluntarily provide to us when you register on the Services, express an interest in obtaining information about us or our products and Services, when you participate in activities on the Services, or otherwise when you contact us.

howWeUseInfo.heading: 2. HOW DO WE PROCESS YOUR INFORMATION?
howWeUseInfo.content: We process your information to provide, improve, and administer our Services, communicate with you, for security and fraud prevention, and to comply with law. We may also process your information for other purposes with your consent.

willInfoBeShared.heading: 3. WHEN AND WITH WHOM DO WE SHARE YOUR PERSONAL INFORMATION?
willInfoBeShared.content: We may share information in specific situations described in this section and/or with the following third parties: with your consent, to comply with laws, to provide you with services, to protect your rights, or to fulfill business obligations.

cookiesAndTracking.heading: 4. DO WE USE COOKIES AND OTHER TRACKING TECHNOLOGIES?
cookiesAndTracking.content: We may use cookies and similar tracking technologies (like web beacons and pixels) to access or store information. Specific information about how we use such technologies is set out in our Cookie Notice.

howLongWeKeepInfo.heading: 5. HOW LONG DO WE KEEP YOUR INFORMATION?
howLongWeKeepInfo.content: We keep your information for as long as necessary to fulfill the purposes outlined in this privacy notice unless otherwise required by law.

howWeKeepInfoSafe.heading: 6. HOW DO WE KEEP YOUR INFORMATION SAFE?
howWeKeepInfoSafe.content: We have implemented appropriate and reasonable technical and organizational security measures designed to protect the security of any personal information we process.

minors.heading: 7. DO WE COLLECT INFORMATION FROM MINORS?
minors.content: We do not knowingly solicit data from or market to children under 18 years of age.

privacyRights.heading: 8. WHAT ARE YOUR PRIVACY RIGHTS?
privacyRights.content: In some regions (like the EEA, UK, and Canada), you have certain rights under applicable data protection laws. These may include the right (i) to request access and obtain a copy of your personal information, (ii) to request rectification or erasure; (iii) to restrict the processing of your personal information; and (iv) if applicable, to data portability.

controlsForDoNotTrack.heading: 9. CONTROLS FOR DO-NOT-TRACK FEATURES
controlsForDoNotTrack.content: Most web browsers and some mobile operating systems and mobile applications include a Do-Not-Track ('DNT') feature or setting you can activate to signal your privacy preference not to have data about your online browsing activities monitored and collected.

updatesToNotice.heading: 10. DO WE MAKE UPDATES TO THIS NOTICE?
updatesToNotice.content: We may update this privacy notice from time to time. The updated version will be indicated by an updated 'Revised' date and the updated version will be effective as soon as it is accessible.

termsOfService.title: Terms of Service
termsOfService.introduction: Welcome to DamDoh! These Terms of Service ('Terms') govern your use of the DamDoh website, applications, and services ('Services'). Please read these Terms carefully before using our Services.

agreementToTerms.heading: 1. Agreement to Terms
agreementToTerms.content: By using our Services, you agree to be bound by these Terms. If you do not agree to these Terms, do not use the Services.

intellectualProperty.heading: 2. Intellectual Property Rights
intellectualProperty.content: We own all rights, title, and interest in and to the Services, including all associated intellectual property rights. You may not use the Services for any commercial purpose without our prior written consent.

userRepresentations.heading: 3. User Representations
userRepresentations.content: By using the Services, you represent and warrant that: (1) all registration information you submit will be true, accurate, current, and complete; (2) you have the legal capacity and you agree to comply with these Terms; (3) you will not use the Services for any illegal or unauthorized purpose.

prohibitedActivities.heading: 4. Prohibited Activities
prohibitedActivities.content: You may not access or use the Services for any purpose other than that for which we make the Services available. Prohibited activity includes, but is not limited to: systematic retrieval of data, tricking or misleading us and other users, or interfering with the security-related features of the Services.

platformManagement.heading: 5. Platform Management
platformManagement.content: We reserve the right, but not the obligation, to: (1) monitor the Services for violations of these Terms; (2) take appropriate legal action against anyone who, in our sole discretion, violates the law or these Terms; (3) in our sole discretion and without limitation, refuse, restrict access to, limit the availability of, or disable any of your Contributions or any portion thereof.

termAndTermination.heading: 6. Term and Termination
termAndTermination.content: These Terms shall remain in full force and effect while you use the Services. WITHOUT LIMITING ANY OTHER PROVISION OF THESE TERMS, WE RESERVE THE RIGHT TO, IN OUR SOLE DISCRETION AND WITHOUT NOTICE OR LIABILITY, DENY ACCESS TO AND USE OF THE SERVICES (INCLUDING BLOCKING CERTAIN IP ADDRESSES), TO ANY PERSON FOR ANY REASON OR FOR NO REASON.

modificationsAndInterruptions.heading: 7. Modifications and Interruptions
modificationsAndInterruptions.content: We reserve the right to change, modify, or remove the contents of the Services at any time or for any reason at our sole discretion without notice. We also reserve the right to modify or discontinue all or part of the Services without notice at any time.

governingLaw.heading: 8. Governing Law
governingLaw.content: These Terms and your use of the Services are governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of Kenya applicable to agreements made and to be entirely performed within Kenya, without regard to its conflict of law principles.

disputeResolution.heading: 9. Dispute Resolution
disputeResolution.content: To expedite resolution and control the cost of any dispute, controversy, or claim related to these Terms, the Parties agree to first attempt to negotiate any Dispute informally for at least thirty (30) days before initiating arbitration.

contactUs.heading: 10. Contact Us
contactUs.content: In order to resolve a complaint regarding the Services or to receive further information regarding use of the Services, please contact us.

termsOfService.conclusion: If you have any questions about these Terms, please {contactLink}.

recipeData.name: Fermented Plant Juice (FPJ)
recipeData.description: A fermented extract of a plant's sap and chlorophylls. Rich in enzymes and microorganisms, it's a potent growth enhancer for plants.
ingredients: 1kg of fast-growing plant parts (e.g., sweet potato tips, bamboo shoots)
steps: Collect plant materials before sunrise when most potent. Do not wash.
Roughly chop the plant materials.
Add an equal weight of brown sugar and mix well.
Pack tightly into a clay pot or glass jar, filling to about 2/3 capacity.
Cover with a breathable cloth and store in a cool, dark place.
Let it ferment for about 7 days.
recipeData.usage: Dilution ratio: 1:500 to 1:1000 with water. Apply as a foliar spray or soil drench.

recipeData.name: Fish Amino Acid (FAA)
recipeData.description: A potent liquid fertilizer made from fish waste, rich in nitrogen and amino acids. Excellent for boosting plant growth.
steps: Chop the fish parts into small pieces.
In a container, layer the fish parts and brown sugar, starting and ending with a layer of sugar.
Fill the container to about 2/3 capacity and cover with a breathable cloth.
Store in a cool, dark place and let it ferment for at least 3-6 months.
recipeData.usage: Dilution ratio: 1:1000 with water. Primarily used as a soil drench.

seedStartingPage.title: Seed Starting Master Guide
seedStartingPage.description: Give your crops the best possible start. Learn the art and science of starting seeds indoors for a stronger, healthier, and more productive season.
seedStartingPage.intro: Starting seeds indoors gives you a major head start on the growing season, protects young plants from pests and harsh weather, and allows you to grow varieties that might not otherwise have time to mature in your climate. This guide will cover the essential steps from choosing your equipment to transplanting your seedlings.

sections.title: Why Start Seeds Indoors?
sections.intro: There are several key advantages to starting seeds indoors versus direct-sowing in the garden:

points.def: Begin weeks or months before your last frost date, which is crucial for plants that take a long time to mature like tomatoes, peppers, and eggplants.
Seedlings are safe from harsh weather (heavy rain, wind, cold snaps) and common pests (slugs, birds, cutworms).
You can control the temperature, moisture, and light to create the perfect conditions for seeds to sprout.
A packet of seeds is far cheaper than buying established nursery plants, especially for large plantings.
You gain access to thousands of unique and heirloom varieties from seed catalogs that you will never find at a local garden center.

sections.title: Key Seed Starting Supplies
sections.intro: Gathering the right supplies before you start will make the process smoother and more successful. You will need:
steps: Containers: Seed trays, cell packs, peat pots, or even recycled yogurt cups (with drainage holes) all work well.
Seed Starting Mix: Use a sterile, soilless mix designed for seed starting. It's lightweight and holds moisture well, preventing diseases that can affect seedlings.
Seeds: Choose high-quality seeds from a reputable supplier. Check the packet for information on planting depth and timing.
Light Source: A sunny, south-facing window can work, but a simple fluorescent shop light or a dedicated LED grow light will provide much better results and prevent 'leggy' (tall and weak) seedlings.
Heat Mat (Optional): Many seeds, especially warm-weather crops like peppers, germinate much faster with bottom heat. A seedling heat mat is a great investment.
Watering Can/Spray Bottle: A gentle way to water your seeds without dislodging them.
Labels: Don't forget to label your trays! Use popsicle sticks, plastic plant tags, or even masking tape.

sections.title: Step-by-Step Planting Guide
sections.intro: Follow these steps to plant your seeds for optimal germination:
steps: Moisten the Mix: Before filling your containers, put your seed-starting mix in a bucket or tub and slowly add warm water, mixing with your hands until it's damp like a wrung-out sponge, but not soggy.
Fill Containers: Fill your containers with the pre-moistened mix, tapping it down gently but not compacting it. Leave about a half-inch of space at the top.
Sow Seeds: Plant 2-3 seeds per cell or pot. A general rule of thumb is to plant a seed twice as deep as it is wide. Check your seed packet for specific instructions.
Cover and Label: Lightly cover the seeds with more mix or vermiculite, then gently firm the surface. Immediately label your tray with the plant variety and the date sown.
Water Gently: Gently water the surface with a spray bottle or water from the bottom by placing your trays in a tub of water. This prevents seeds from washing away.

Provide Warmth & Cover: Place trays in a warm spot or on a heat mat. Cover with a plastic dome or plastic wrap to retain humidity until seeds sprout. Remove the cover as soon as you see the first signs of green.

sections.title: Caring for Your Seedlings
sections.intro: Once your seeds have germinated, their needs change. Proper care now is crucial for strong plants.
steps: Light is Critical: As soon as seeds sprout, they need abundant light. Place them under grow lights for 14-16 hours a day, keeping the lights just a few inches above the tops of the plants. If using a window, rotate trays daily to prevent leaning.
Watering: Keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Watering from the bottom is often best to encourage deep root growth.

Thinning: Once seedlings have their first set of 'true leaves' (the second pair that appears), choose the strongest-looking seedling in each cell and snip the others at the soil line with scissors. This avoids disturbing the winner's roots.
Fertilizing: Begin feeding your seedlings with a diluted, balanced liquid fertilizer (at quarter strength) after they have 2-3 sets of true leaves. Feed about once a week.
Air Circulation: A gentle fan blowing on your seedlings for a few hours a day helps prevent disease and strengthens their stems.

sections.title: Hardening Off & Transplanting
sections.intro: 'Hardening off' is the process of gradually acclimating your tender, indoor-grown plants to the harsh conditions outdoors.
steps: Start 1-2 Weeks Before Transplanting: About 7-14 days before your local last frost date, begin the process.
Day 1: Place seedlings in a shady, protected spot outdoors for 1-2 hours.
Gradual Exposure: Each day, increase the amount of time they spend outside by an hour or two, gradually introducing them to more direct sunlight and wind.
Bring Indoors: Bring plants back inside each night if temperatures drop significantly.
Transplant: After a week or two of hardening off, your plants are ready for their new home in the garden. Choose a calm, overcast day to transplant to minimize shock. Water them in well.

sections.title: Common Mistakes to Avoid
sections.intro: Avoid these common pitfalls for a more successful seed-starting experience:

points.def: This is the most common cause of seedling death. It leads to 'damping off', a fungal disease that rots the stems at the soil line. Allow the soil surface to dry slightly between waterings.
Causes 'leggy', weak seedlings that stretch for light. If you don't have grow lights, a very bright south-facing window is the next best thing.
Eagerness is great, but starting seeds too soon results in large, root-bound plants that struggle after transplanting. Check your seed packet and count back from your local last frost date.
Overcrowded seedlings compete for light and nutrients, resulting in weak plants for all. It's tough, but thinning is necessary for strong individual plants.

familyFarmPage.title: Integrated Family Farm Model (200 sqm)
familyFarmPage.description: A holistic, diversified model for a small family farm designed for resilience, nutritional security, and supplemental income.
familyFarmPage.intro: This model demonstrates how a small plot of land (e.g. 20m x 10m) can be transformed into a productive, integrated system that mimics natural ecosystems. It combines different elements that support each other, reducing waste and minimizing external inputs while maximizing diversity and yield.
familyFarmPage.diagramCaption: Conceptual diagram of the 200 sqm integrated family farm model.

zones.title: Overall Layout & Principles
zones.imageAlt: An overview of a lush, diversified small farm.
description: The 200 square meter (20m x 10m) plot is designed for intensive, regenerative production. The core idea is to create a closed-loop system where each component supports another, minimizing waste and maximizing resource use.

Water is the central, life-giving element, with the pond acting as a reservoir, nutrient source, and habitat. The layout is designed to use gravity and natural flows for irrigation and nutrient distribution.

subSections.title: Resource Cycling
content: Waste from one component becomes a resource for another (e.g., chicken manure fertilizes the crops, crop residues feed the chickens).

subSections.title: Diversity over Monoculture
content: A wide variety of plants and animals creates resilience against pests and diseases.

subSections.title: Vertical Stacking
content: Using trellises and multi-story cropping to maximize yield in a small space.

subSections.title: Edge Effect
content: The boundary between the pond and the land is a highly productive zone for moisture-loving plants.

zones.title: Raised Vegetable & Herb Beds (100 sqm)
zones.imageAlt: Lush raised beds with a variety of greens and herbs.
description: This is the primary food production area, occupying half the total space. Raised beds improve drainage, reduce soil compaction, and are easier to manage.
Intensive planting methods like intercropping (planting different crops together) and succession planting (immediately replanting after harvest) are used to maximize production throughout the year.

details.title: Crops
content: Leafy greens (lettuce, spinach), root vegetables (carrots, radishes), fruiting vegetables (tomatoes, peppers), legumes (beans, peas), and essential culinary/medicinal herbs.

details.title: Fertility
content: Maintained by compost from the farm's waste, chicken manure, and nutrient-rich water from the fish pond.

zones.title: Fruit Trees & Perennials (Integrated)
zones.imageAlt: A small orchard with various fruit trees and perennials.
description: Fruit trees are integrated along the borders and within the vegetable beds to provide a long-term food source, create microclimates, and add vertical structure.
These perennial plants require less annual labor than vegetables and help build soil stability with their deep root systems.

details.title: Examples
content: Dwarf varieties of banana, papaya, mango, and citrus trees are excellent choices for small spaces. Perennials like moringa or passionfruit on a trellis can also be integrated.

zones.title: Fish Pond (15 sqm)
zones.imageAlt: A small, clear fish pond with tilapia and aquatic plants.
description: The fish pond is a key element of the integrated system. It acts as a water reservoir for irrigation during dry periods and provides a source of protein.
The nutrient-rich water from the pond, full of fish excretions, is a natural, high-quality liquid fertilizer for the vegetable beds.

details.title: Species
content: Tilapia is a popular choice as they are hardy, fast-growing, and primarily vegetarian.

details.title: Aquatic Plants
content: Water spinach or duckweed can be grown on the surface, providing feed for the fish and chickens, as well as for human consumption.

zones.title: Chicken Coop (5 sqm)
zones.imageAlt: A small, clean chicken coop with a few hens.
description: A small flock of chickens (5-10) provides a constant source of eggs and meat for the family.
Their manure is a potent fertilizer for the compost pile, and they can be allowed to forage in harvested garden beds to clean up pests and weed seeds.

details.title: Integration
content: Positioning the coop next to the compost pile allows for easy transfer of manure. The chickens are fed kitchen scraps and excess garden produce, reducing waste.

zones.title: Compost & Waste Management Area
description: This is the farm's recycling center. All organic 'waste'—kitchen scraps, garden trimmings, animal manure, and fallen leaves—is converted into 'black gold' (compost).
A simple three-bin system allows one pile to be actively built, one to be 'cooking', and one to be ready for use, ensuring a continuous supply of high-quality soil amendment.

details.title: Function
content: Closes the nutrient loop on the farm, eliminating the need for synthetic fertilizers, improving soil structure, and increasing its water-holding capacity.

conclusion.title: A Model of Abundance
content: This 200 sqm model is more than just a farm; it is a living example of how to work with nature to create abundance in a small space.

It provides a diverse and nutritious diet, reduces reliance on external markets, generates potential surplus for income, and builds a resilient system that can better withstand climate and economic shocks.
It is a pathway to food sovereignty and a healthier life for the family.
